I believe that Jason has a point, when you test a method in certain scenario 
you have some preconditions and postconditions.

In the example given, the postconditions where related with the method 
execution scenario but not with each other. So, it's possible for one to 
fail but not the others.

Maybe, one could test each postcondition isolated, but if the scenario is 
the same for all this test, that mean you are going to be duplicating a lot.

I think there are two choices:
1. a test per scenario, nevermind unrelated postconditions
2. a test per postcondition, use a setup for the same scenario

I prefer the first, because it seems quicker, and I don't think I'll be 
loosing that much. But I'm not an expert on testing... just giving my first 
steps. 

Regards,
Mariano Cortesi
